bibl.title: Letter from Juan Guiteras to Henry Rose Carter, June 28, 1924

div1.p: Guiteras critiques Carter's yellow fever manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Juan Guiteras to Henry Rose Carter, June 28, 1924
div1.opener:
DR. JUAN GUITERAS
--
Benavides
June 28, 1924
Dear Dr. Carter
div1.p:
I enclose the last of the M.S. you have sent me,
and I shall miss the pleasure of reading through your proof. The sub-
ject, as you well know, is interesting to me, and then you present it
in such attractive form. I am almost sorry to have said that you might
leave out some matter that does not bear directly on the subject; but
see whether you don't obscure the discussion.

The end of this part of your M.S. (177-215) I can't crticise
in any way that might be of help to you. All my library, except
Spanish and English literature, I have given to the Library of Matan-
zas,. I have no yellow fever literature with me, and cannot bring out
facts in su support of my views; but all I have said with respect to
Yucatan will give you the key of the argument I would use to explain
your long periods of apparent freedom from yellow fever.
I have tried to be of help to tou with brief comment.
div1.closer:
Love to Laura. Sincerely your friend Juan Guiteras P. 197. line 6. “they were more yellow than coins” Is'nt this “coings,”
“quince.” Later on you have coings.
P. 205, line 13. “El vecindario” means the civilians as contrasted
with the military.

Take upon corresponding pages of office
copy, which is the one to be used by
in retyping-
By
L. G. C-
